//Imperial Needle
//notes: adam (PvE 1 / primary use / optimal): Lightweight bows have a draw time stat cap of 540. Elastic String gets you to this cap by itself, making a draw time MW useless. If you don't have Elastic String on your roll, a Draw Time MW also becomes valuable. The best min/max combo is Polymer String with a Draw Time MW, as it results in a couple points of extra Accuracy but it's not worth losing sleep over, the main thing that matters is reaching the Draw Time cap. Archer's Tempo does give an increase beyond the cap of 540, but only a minor one—its benefits are more noticable if you haven't reached that cap, so if you have reached the cap with any combination of String + MW stat bonuses, the reload increase from Impulse Amplifier probably gives you a slightly higher DPS increase.|tags:PvE

//Threaded Needle
//notes: adam (PvE / boss DPS / optimal): Slot 2 is a tricky one with LFRs: Accelerated coils gives you the best DPS, Ionized Battery the best total damage for a single mag, Liquid Coils is a middle-ground option with more total damage than Accelerated, and faster reloads than Ionized. There is no clear winner here, the best one will be situational based on the length of the damage phase (can you empty all your ammo despite a reload penalty? — if so, Ionized Mag is the winner) and how much damage you need to do (if you don't need to go out of your way to optimize total damage output, take Accelerated)|tags:PvE
dimwishlist:item=3075224551&perks=839105230,689005463,2869569095,1546637391
dimwishlist:item=3075224551&perks=839105230,1483536627,2869569095,1546637391
dimwishlist:item=3075224551&perks=689005463,2869569095,1546637391
dimwishlist:item=3075224551&perks=1483536627,2869569095,1546637391

There is no clear winner here, the best one will be situational based on the length of the damage phase (can you empty all your ammo despite a reload penalty? — if so, Ionized Mag is the winner) and how much damage you need to do (if you don't need to go out of your way to optimize total damage output, take Accelerated)|tags:PvE

//Code Duello
//notes: adam (PvE / boss DPS / optimal): Field prep maxes reload speed as long as you're crouched. You're most likely going to use this one in a sustained raid boss phase, where you're usually stationary in a well, so staying crouched shouldn't be an issue. Impulse Amplifier also gives a reload buff, the extent of which I'm not sure about, but even if it maxes reload similar to field prep, the extra reserves granted by Field Prep greatly increase your total damage potential, making it a superior choice.|tags:PvE
dimwishlist:item=2496242052&perks=3796465595,2869569095,3927722942
dimwishlist:item=2496242052&perks=2869569095,3927722942

//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): Subsistence is great on hand cannons when used for general add clear. By default, this gun gets 1 bullet back for every kill with subsistence—however, a mag increase in Slot 2 can push that to 2 per kill, which should guarantee an infinite mag without ever having to reload.  That being said, I would look for the High PL Content roll, which covers all PvE situations really well.|tags:PvE

//The Palindrome
//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs / optimal): One For All is a no-brainer as a GM damage perk. Subsistence would be extremely punishing partly because of the hit your reserves take, and with how tanky enemies are, you'd need to use more bullets per kill than what is auto-reloaded in return. Due to how hard it can be to kill GM enemies with a primary (and with the RNG-factor involved with Overflow), it should be worth stacking reload stat increases in Slot 2 and with your Masterwork in case you can't proc your reload perk.|tags:PvE

//The Palindrome (Adept)
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): Subsistence feels viable on hand cannons, if you use them to clear add waves. By default, this gun gets 1 bullet back for every kill with subsistence—however, a mag increase in Slot 2 can push that to 2 per kill, which should guarantee an infinite mag without ever having to reload. Keep in mind though that the higher your mag, the more subsistence lowers your total reserves. That being said, I would look for the roll below, which covers both easy red bar clear and difficult content as well.|tags:PvE

//The Third Axiom
//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs / optimal): One For All should make this hit hard in GMs, and Disruption Break can help you prime barrier champions for kills with your kinetic. Since the only traditional reload perk available is Feeding Frenzy—which really suffers in a GM context—you will want to go for reload stat increases here. If you can't get that perfect stat package, you should probably only pull this out if you specifically need an arc pulse for match game shield management—which suddenly makes Genesis desirable considering the use case.|tags:PvE

//Xenoclast IV
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): As always, Smoothbore in Slot 1 is a hard no for any pvp shotgun. Otherwise, Killing Wind is probably the most interesting thing here. With the +20 intrinsic mobility buff from lightweight frames, and the 6-second +50 mobility buff from Killing Wind, you could pair this with the Powerful Friends mod (also +20) to have 100 effective mobility after a kill with just 10 mobility on your armor set, allowing you to focus your armor on other stats. Hunters can pair it with Dragon's Shadow, which gives +50 mobility for 10 seconds after a dodge to make it even more consistent, giving that 100 effective mobility even before the kill. Dragon's Shadow lets you secure the kill more easily, Killing Wind can extend the mobility buff while Dragon's Shadow is on cooldown, making for a good loop.|tags:PvP
dimwishlist:item=2891672170&perks=1047830412,791862061,3161816588,2450788523
dimwishlist:item=2891672170&perks=1047830412,791862061,3161816588,2726471870
dimwishlist:item=2891672170&perks=1047830412,791862061,1866048759,2450788523
dimwishlist:item=2891672170&perks=1047830412,791862061,1866048759,2726471870
dimwishlist:item=2891672170&perks=1047830412,791862061,2450788523
dimwishlist:item=2891672170&perks=1047830412,791862061,2726471870

//Royal Entry
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Should be a great legendary option thanks to the combo of tracking + Chain Reaction. //Stars In Shadow
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): This archetype synergizes well with Headseeker, giving you a more forgiving 2-burst kill: 2 shots to the body and 4 to the head will down any guardian below 8 resilience. So if you aim around the oppponent's head and land the first shot in each burst on the body, Headseeker gives you a 2-burst kill.|tags:PvP

//Frozen Orbit
//notes: adam (PvE / optimal): Primarily recommend this for GMs, as Rapid-Fire Frames outclass Aggressives when it comes to pure DPS, even with Vorpal factored in. However, more damage per bullet makes Aggressives very strong in a GM context where ammo economy can play a big role. Appended Mag is my recommended option in Slot 2 as it gives +1 mag increase by itself and +2 combined with a Backup Mag mod. Tactical Mag will give +1 by itself along with a reload speed buff, but Backup Mag doesn't buff it past that, recommend using Boss/Major spec with it instead.|tags:PvE

//Frozen Orbit
//notes: adam (PvP / general use / optimal): Probably the best PvP sniper at the moment. It's an Aggressive Frame with Snapshot (the most essential sniper perk after the Quickdraw nerf), giving you instant body shot kills with any damage buff depending on the opponent's resilience. Without a buff, body shots will still do enough damage to allow instant cleanups with your primary.|tags:PvP

//Bottom Dollar
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Rangefinder combined with the high base range on 120s frees you up to focus on stability boosts in the first two columns. Without RF, you might want to split those stats between range and stability based on personal preference. Slot 4 will depend on your playstyle: Opening Shot gets you an additional range cushion similar to Rangefinder, and helps guarantee that first hit, which can be enough to scare opponents into panic plays considering how much damage 120s deal. Explosive Payload flinches the opponent like few other things. Rampage lets you 2-tap anyone after just one kill but you need to be an aggressive player who doesn't seek cover after downing an opponent.|tags:PvP

//Crowd Pleaser
//notes: adam (PvE / boss DPS / optimal): The damage increase from Spike Grenades increases as your blast radius decreases. Because of this, your DPS will take a hit with any Slot 1 perk that increases blast radius, or with a blast radius MW.  Field Prep gives you the best traditional reload speed but Pulse Monitor can max DPS: if you fire the last shot in the mag at your feet while standing in a Well, you get an instant reload. Slot 4 has the least impact here but Demolitionist can get you a free reload (or multiple if you use Starfire Protocol) during a damage phase, slightly increasing your overall DPS.|tags:PvE
dimwishlist:item=3565520715&perks=981914802,3301904089,2869569095,3523296417
dimwishlist:item=3565520715&perks=981914802,3301904089,972757866,3523296417
dimwishlist:item=3565520715&perks=981914802,3301904089,2869569095
dimwishlist:item=3565520715&perks=981914802,3301904089,972757866
dimwishlist:item=3565520715&perks=3301904089,2869569095,3523296417
dimwishlist:item=3565520715&perks=3301904089,972757866,3523296417
dimwishlist:item=3565520715&perks=3301904089,2869569095
dimwishlist:item=3565520715&perks=3301904089,972757866

//Crowd Pleaser
//notes: adam (PvE / boss DPS): The damage increase from Spike Grenades increases as your blast radius decreases. Because of this, your DPS will take a hit with any Slot 1 perk that increases blast radius, or with a blast radius MW.  Field Prep gives you the best traditional reload speed but Pulse Monitor can max DPS: if you fire the last shot in the mag at your feet while standing in a Well, you get an instant reload. Slot 4 has the least impact here but Demolitionist can get you a free reload (or multiple if you use Starfire Protocol) during a damage phase, slightly increasing your overall DPS.|tags:PvE
dimwishlist:item=3565520715&perks=981914802,3301904089,2284787283,3523296417

dimwishlist:item=3717177717&perks=1820235745,4049631843

//Multimach CCX
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Difficult to pin down an obvious god roll with this one (inspect your roll, even if it's wishlisted!). Its perk pool allows you to create combinations that result in either the highest range or the highest stability SMG in the game. This archetype really needs you to hit your crits (as it sports the fastest optimal TTK but the slowest body shot TTK among SMGs) which means you should only go for the range stacking if you're fully confident in your ability to control against recoil. You could try stacking enough range stat boosts to counteract the penalty from Iron Gaze, which would yield an average range gun with really high aim assist. At the end of the day, the most reliable option for quickplay might just be Kill Clip with a balanced stat distribution (and an SMG in 3v3 doesn't feel viable).|tags:PvP
dimwishlist:item=3717177717&perks=663495154,1431678320,2450788523,1015611457
dimwishlist:item=3717177717&perks=663495154,1431678320,2450788523,11551321

//notes: adam (PvP): Difficult to pin down an obvious god roll with this one (inspect your roll, even if it's wishlisted!). This archetype really needs you to hit your crits (as it sports the fastest optimal TTK but the slowest body shot TTK among SMGs) which means you should only go for the range stacking if you're fully confident in your ability to control against recoil. A truly perfect roll would have one of the long rifle zooms and a shorter zoom as the Slot 1 options, that way you can respec based on the map you are playing on. Long zooms get preference though because of the huge range boost they provide.|tags:PvP

//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): You are ideally looking for a combo between Slot 1, Slot 2, and the Masterwork that lets you boost both range and stability. //The Fool's Remedy
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Iron Gaze seems like a pretty bad tradeoff on paper, until you realize that due to their positioning as a close-quarters primary, sidearms only get minor increases from that stat. The actual distance loss from Iron Gaze is only 1 meter, and in exchange you get a gun that can hit a full 100 aim assist stat if you combine it with Moving Target and a Targeting mod on your helmet (still 93 without Moving Target, and you get the hip-fire benefit). It's a unique roll that synergizes extremely well with this particular weapon type, and should feel amazing for controller players. Your other option is Iron Grip for that stability boost, which provides another way of helping you hit your shots.|tags:PvP

//notes: adam (PvP): Iron Gaze seems like a pretty bad tradeoff on paper, until you realize that due to their positioning as a close-quarters primary, sidearms only get minor increases from that stat. //Trustee
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): I am leaning towards Outlaw on a general PvE roll, since you might not have enough downtime on your primary to give enough time for Reconstruction to do its job. That being said, the right mag perks can give you a good enough reload speed that you can get by without Outlaw, and take advantage of that double mag. Don't be fooled by the rarity and novelty on Redirection, it's a weak buff and I'd always pick Wellspring over it. Lastly, avoid the Reconstruction + High-Impact Reserves combo, as the latter only procs on the second half of your *base* mag, and the auto-refill from Reconstruction means you might never get it to proc. Try to get Arrowhead Brake to stabilize the pretty bad recoil deviation on this weapon.|tags:PvE
dimwishlist:item=1392919471&perks=839105230,106909392,1168162263,3592538738
dimwishlist:item=1392919471&perks=839105230,3177308360,1168162263,3592538738
dimwishlist:item=1392919471&perks=839105230,1087426260,1168162263,3592538738
dimwishlist:item=1392919471&perks=839105230,106909392,1168162263

dimwishlist:item=1392919471&perks=839105230,1168162263,3592538738
dimwishlist:item=1392919471&perks=839105230,1168162263

//Trustee
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content): I am leaning towards Outlaw on a general PvE roll, since you might not have enough downtime on your primary to give enough time for Reconstruction to do its job. That being said, the right mag perks can give you a good enough reload speed that you can get by without Outlaw, and take advantage of that double mag. Don't be fooled by the rarity and novelty on Redirection, it's a weak buff and I'd always pick Wellspring over it. Lastly, avoid the Reconstruction + High-Impact Reserves combo, as the latter only procs on the second half of your *base* mag, and the auto-refill from Reconstruction means you might never get it to proc. Try to get Arrowhead Brake to stabilize the pretty bad recoil deviation on this weapon.|tags:PvE

//Trustee
//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs / optimal): The double mag from Reconstruction should be more useful in GMs, both for champion stuns and for whittling down tankier enemies. Also, you will have your special and heavy out for far longer in these activities, which lets the auto-refill tick up in the background. Redirection should be somewhat more useful here, but you're still much better off using your special on a GM elite. It's a passive benefit, which is always great, but a very minor one. Once again, try to get Arrowhead Brake to stabilize the pretty bad recoil deviation on this weapon.|tags:PvE

//Succession
//notes: adam (PvE / optimal): Extended Mag + Reconstruction + a Backup Mag mod gets you 10 shots in the mag, basically removing the need for reloads entirely. Osmosis is an extremely powerful tool on this weapon due to its archetype's viability in end-game activities, where Match Game is often enabled. With Osmosis, you get a lot of loadout versatility, and could easily cover all 3 shield elements with your weapons. For damage perks, I personally prefer Vorpal's reliability over Recombination's more powerful buff with its limited uptime.|tags:PvE
dimwishlist:item=2990047042&perks=839105230,2420895100,1523832109,1546637391
dimwishlist:item=2990047042&perks=839105230,2420895100,1523832109,1774574192
dimwishlist:item=2990047042&perks=1840239774,2420895100,1523832109,1546637391

dimwishlist:item=2990047042&perks=2420895100,1523832109,1774574192

//Succession
//notes: adam (PvE): Extended Mag + Reconstruction + a Backup Mag mod gets you 10 shots in the mag, basically removing the need for reloads entirely. Osmosis is an extremely powerful tool on this weapon due to its archetype's viability in end-game activities, where Match Game is often enabled. With Osmosis, you get a lot of loadout versatility, and could easily cover all 3 shield elements with your weapons. For damage perks, I personally prefer Vorpal's reliability over Recombination's more powerful buff with its limited uptime.|tags:PvE

//Commemoration
//notes: adam (PvE / optimal): The base mag on this maxes out at 75 rounds (Reconstruction pushes that to 150), which you can achieve by combining a Backup Mag mod with any of the Tactical, Appended, and Extended Mag perks. However, Extended Mag by itself gets you to 72 (144 with Reconstruction), getting you close to the max while still providing you with the ability to use Rampage Spec or Dragonfly Spec to empower your damage dealing perk. If you can't get Extended Mag to roll, put a Backup Mag mod on it, which will boost you to 72 or 75 depending on your Slot 2 roll.|tags:PvE

//Commemoration
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): PvP heavy bricks give more ammo the higher your mag size, so you will either need Extended Mag here or you will always want a Backup Mag on the weapon to get to max ammo per brick. Extended + Backup Mag gives no extra ammo pickup so if you manage to roll Extended, you are free to use any other mod on the weapon. Under Pressure will always be active, as the ammo you get from a brick is less than half your mag size.|tags:PvP

//Finite Impactor
//notes: adam (PvE / optimal): The lack of any traditional reload perks makes this hard to recommend as a PvE gun at first glance. However, it is the only 140 rpm hand cannon that can roll Heating Up. This could be a really good QoL perk on hand cannons, and I think it might be worth testing one, especially if you can get a good combination of Slot 2 + MW all optimized for increasing the reload speed stat. Combined with certain exotics, or HC loader mods, it could make up for the lack of a dedicated reload perk, resulting in a weapon that feels very good to use and can dish out a lot of damage with One For All.|tags:PvE
dimwishlist:item=3813153080&perks=1926090095,3230963543,1570042021,4049631843
dimwishlist:item=3813153080&perks=1926090094,3230963543,1570042021,4049631843
dimwishlist:item=3813153080&perks=3230963543,1570042021,4049631843

//Finite Impactor
//notes: adam (PvE): The lack of any traditional reload perks makes this hard to recommend as a PvE gun at first glance. However, it is the only 140 rpm hand cannon that can roll Heating Up. This could be a really good QoL perk on hand cannons, and I think it might be worth testing one, especially if you can get a good combination of Slot 2 + MW all optimized for increasing the reload speed stat. Combined with certain exotics, or HC loader mods, it could make up for the lack of a dedicated reload perk, resulting in a weapon that feels very good to use and can dish out a lot of damage with One For All.|tags:PvE
dimwishlist:item=3813153080&perks=1926090095,679225683,1570042021,4049631843
dimwishlist:item=3813153080&perks=1926090094,679225683,1570042021,4049631843
dimwishlist:item=3813153080&perks=679225683,1570042021,4049631843

//Riiswalker
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): This is a must-have shotgun for PvP, capable of rolling Quickdraw, and up to 96(!) Range. It also comes in the kinetic slot, where we sorely needed an alternative to Astral Horizon that regular mortals could reasonably acquire. Being a Lightweight Frame, it has slightly shorter OHK distances than the Aggressives, but the ridiculous range stat and its faster fire rate (especially with Assault Mag) lets you get quick two-shot kills from slug ranges, consistently outdueling the aggressives in the 8-11 meter range. I think there are two viable rolls here: Quickdraw combined with either Full Choke or Rifled Barrel* is the classic shotgun roll, but I think the newly buffed Hip-Fire Grip and Rifled Barrel** could potentially work well if you don't like ADSing with your shotguns, and should be worth testing if you get that combo. On this weapon in particular, I think Surplus could work in place of Quickdraw due to the high base handling, making it close-to-quickdraw fast with just one ability banked. *I think Full Choke will be more potent here, lightweights need to hit 11 out of 12 pellets to kill, so tightening the spread is crucial. **Full Choke only triggers if you ADS, which makes it a bad combo with Hip-Fire Grip|tags:PvP
dimwishlist:item=108221785&perks=1047830412,3142289711,706527188,591790007
dimwishlist:item=108221785&perks=1047830412,791862061,706527188,591790007
dimwishlist:item=108221785&perks=1332244541,3142289711,706527188,591790007

//Occluded Finality
//notes: adam (PvP / general use / optimal): It's an aggressive sniper with ricochet rounds! That's cool. What's not so cool is that it has a zoom level of 58 (for comparison, both Frozen Orbit and Succession are 50 zooms, and most of the other snipers around are either 50 or below), which could make it hard to use at certain ranges. But if you can get used to it, Opening Shot and the high zoom level should give it some really generous aim assist, and landing the occassional ricochet kill should feel incredible.|tags:PvP
dimwishlist:item=852551895&perks=1840239774,1885400500,957782887,47981717
dimwishlist:item=852551895&perks=839105230,1885400500,957782887,47981717
dimwishlist:item=852551895&perks=4090651448,1885400500,957782887,47981717
dimwishlist:item=852551895&perks=1885400500,957782887,47981717

//Occluded Finality
//notes: adam (PvP / for Arc sublcasses / optimal): Yes, it is a 58 zoom sniper, which sucks, but if you can get used to that, this roll is something special: on an arc subclass, the combination of Arrowhead Brake, Elemental Capacitor, and a Handling MW give you a perfect 100 Handling and a perfect 100 Recoil Stat (without the Handling MW, you still get 91 Handling, or 96 if you go for Fluted Barrel and sacrifice some Recoil correction). By comparison, a Frozen Orbit with as much handling stacked on it as possible maxes out at 50!  So you have an Aggressive Frame sniper that can body shot under certain resilience levels, with classic Quickdraw-equivalent draw/stow/ADS speeds, and it even has ricochet rounds, allowing you to bank shots around corners! And because the handling stat is so high, you can afford to forgo Snapshot, which opens up Mulligan as an option to end up with a budget-Revoker. What a wild weapon this could be.|tags:PvP
dimwishlist:item=852551895&perks=1840239774,1885400500,3337692349,3511092054
dimwishlist:item=852551895&perks=1840239774,1885400500,2866798147,3511092054
dimwishlist:item=852551895&perks=839105230,1885400500,3337692349,3511092054

//Chroma Rush
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): There are a couple of good reload perks available here for Slot 3 but this gun can be really good even if you're missing one, combining a relatively fast base reload speed with the rapid-fire archetype's intrinsic ability to reload faster on an empty magazine. That intrinsic ability stacks multiplicatively with Alloy Magazine: if you can grab that roll, just hold down the trigger until you run out, and you will get an incredibly fast reload at the end. Since the archetype incentivizes using up your ammo, Rampage will the best available damage perk (as the only one that doesn't require constant reloads).|tags:PvE

//Chroma Rush
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Kill Clip is your best damage perk on this one, and it becomes quite powerful when it's active. Tunnel Vision is the obvious pairing, as it also activates on reload, but I think I prefer Moving Target: it gives very similar benefits, but it's active even before the first kill, increasing your chances to get Kill Clip going. For the rest of the roll, you really need to stack Range, as this close-quarters archetype will need all the help it can get to not get outgunned by the longer ranged hand cannons and pulses.|tags:PvP
dimwishlist:item=1119734784&perks=3250034553,3142289711,588594999,1015611457
dimwishlist:item=1119734784&perks=3250034553,3142289711,588594999,1015611457

//Farewell
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): Nothing particularly surprising here, a strong, solid gun from the highest-DPS sidearm archetype with a great damage perk option in Slot 4, and a lot of QoL options in Slot 3. Try to get some reload stat increases as there are no perks to speed it up, and even Subsistence will run out of bullets eventually. Full Auto is either a must have or a worthless perk depending on how well your joints handle the rapid clicking sidearms require without it. Adjust your preferences accordingly.|tags:PvE

//Farewell
//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs / optimal): The low range on sidearms can make them awkward to use in long-range GM fights but Rangefinder helps this one get some extra room before damage falloff kicks in. Unfortunately, there are no great damage perks available, but if you can get into range, this archetype can do alright without one, and Adrenaline Junkie or Frenzy can still give you the occassional burst you need. Full Auto is either a must have or a worthless perk depending on how well your joints handle the rapid clicking sidearms require without it. Adjust your preferences accordingly.|tags:PvE

//Farewell
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): If you like sidearms in PvP, this is very much worth a pickup. Very fast TTK (0.67 even before you get Multikill Clip or a possible Surprise Attack mod build going), and either an extra range boost with Rangefinder, or extremely reliably stability/aim assist help with any of the other perks on the list. Sidearms don't get much out of range stat stacking, so I'd try boosting stability and/or recoil first, then focus any extra slots on range. Full Auto is either a must have or a worthless perk depending on how well your joints handle the rapid clicking sidearms require without it. Adjust your preferences accordingly.|tags:PvP

//Farewell
//notes: adam (PvP): If you like sidearms in PvP, this is very much worth a pickup. Very fast TTK (0.67 even before you get Multikill Clip or a possible Surprise Attack mod build going), and either an extra range boost with Rangefinder, or extremely reliably stability/aim assist help with any of the other perks on the list. Sidearms don't get much out of range stat stacking, so I'd try boosting stability and/or recoil first, then focus any extra slots on range. Full Auto is either a must have or a worthless perk depending on how well your joints handle the rapid clicking sidearms require without it. Adjust your preferences accordingly.|tags:PvP

//Gridskipper
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): Rapid-fire pulses can feel really good, and this doesn't exactly disappoint However, I find its base reload speed a little too slow, and there are no dedicated reload perks available. Not an unsolvable problem, as it is a rapid-fire frame, which gets an intrinsic boost to reloads with an empty magazine. Combine this with Alloy Magazine, and you should be able to overcome that handicap to end up with the closest replacement we've had to Claws of the Wolf. Adrenaline Junkie can be valuable on this for Warlocks, as it is a void weapon that can proc Nezarec's Sin. Otherwise, Multikill Clip is your best option for a damage increase, and the other slots have some amazing options for stability/recoil/aim assist boosts so you can just spray away.|tags:PvE
dimwishlist:item=1621558458&perks=839105230,1431678320,2946784966,2458213969
dimwishlist:item=1621558458&perks=839105230,1431678320,1570042021,2458213969
dimwishlist:item=1621558458&perks=839105230,1431678320,2450788523,2458213969

//Gridskipper
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content): Rapid-fire pulses can feel really good, and this doesn't exactly disappoint However, I find its base reload speed a little too slow, and there are no dedicated reload perks available. Not an unsolvable problem, as it is a rapid-fire frame, which gets an intrinsic boost to reloads with an empty magazine. Combine this with Alloy Magazine, and you should be able to overcome that handicap to end up with the closest replacement we've had to Claws of the Wolf. Adrenaline Junkie can be valuable on this for Warlocks, as it is a void weapon that can proc Nezarec's Sin. Otherwise, Multikill Clip is your best option for a damage increase, and the other slots have some amazing options for stability/recoil/aim assist boosts so you can just spray away.|tags:PvE

//Gridskipper
//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs / optimal): Rapid-fire pulses can feel really good, and this doesn't exactly disappoint However, I find its base reload speed a little too slow, and there are no dedicated reload perks available. Not an unsolvable problem, as it is a rapid-fire frame, which gets an intrinsic boost to reloads with an empty magazine. Combine this with Alloy Magazine, and you should be able to overcome that handicap to end up with the closest replacement we've had to Claws of the Wolf. Adrenaline Junkie can be valuable on this for Warlocks, as it is a void weapon that can proc Nezarec's Sin.|tags:PvE

//Gridskipper
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Moving Target is the only major perk on here worth using that doesn't require a kill to proc. I'd usually consider that an issue but this gun already feels good to use by default, and once you get that first kill, the combined aim assist + stablity + damage combo you get from the other perks turns it into an absolute menace. Highly recommended, but it does require thoughtful play due to its relatively low range compared to some of the popular meta weapons.|tags:PvP

//Ignition Code
//notes: adam (PvE / general use / optimal): Slideshot is a game changer here, and I mean that literally: you will have to adapt your playstyle, and get used to sliding after every shot, but once you make the adjustments, this becomes a grenade launcher that functions like they did in the old luna-reload days, able to pump out shots as fast as its RPM, with reloading entirely removed from the equation. I'd recommend farming this until you have both spike and blinding, they are equally valuable options depending on the situation.|tags:PvE

//Ignition Code
//notes: adam (PvE / general use): Slideshot is a game changer here, and I mean that literally: you will have to adapt your playstyle, and get used to sliding after every shot, but once you make the adjustments, this becomes a grenade launcher that functions like they did in the old luna-reload days, able to pump out shots as fast as its RPM, with reloading entirely removed from the equation. I'd recommend farming this until you have both spike and blinding, they are equally valuable options depending on the situation.|tags:PvE

//Ignition Code
//notes: adam (PvE / single target dps / optimal): Slideshot is a game changer here, and I mean that literally: you will have to adapt your playstyle, and get used to sliding after every shot, but once you make the adjustments, this becomes a grenade launcher that functions like they did in the old luna-reload days, able to pump out shots as fast as its RPM, with reloading entirely removed from the equation. If you don't want to make that leap, or the boss encounter lacks space for movement, Field Prep is your next best option, for both the extra reserves and the maxed reload speed.|tags:PvE
dimwishlist:item=304659313&perks=981914802,3301904089,3161816588,1546637391

//Ignition Code
//notes: adam (PvE / single target dps): Slideshot is a game changer here, and I mean that literally: you will have to adapt your playstyle, and get used to sliding after every shot, but once you make the adjustments, this becomes a grenade launcher that functions like they did in the old luna-reload days, able to pump out shots as fast as its RPM, with reloading entirely removed from the equation. If you don't want to make that leap, or the boss encounter lacks space for movement, Field Prep is your next best option, for both the extra reserves and the maxed reload speed.|tags:PvE
dimwishlist:item=304659313&perks=981914802,3301904089,3161816588,1546637391
dimwishlist:item=304659313&perks=981914802,3301904089,2869569095,1546637391
dimwishlist:item=304659313&perks=3301904089,3161816588,1546637391
dimwishlist:item=304659313&perks=3301904089,2869569095,1546637391

//Ignition Code
//notes: adam (PvE / blinding / optimal): Danger Zone is a truly special perk when it comes to Blinding Grenade builds: Blinding Grenades apply a -200 Blast Radius penalty, which normally ensures that any GL that has them equipped has the same minimum Blast Radius, no matter how many stat boosts you stack onto them. However, when active, Danger Zone seems to set the weapon's Blast Radius to max, ignoring any stat modifiers like the one applied by Blinding Grenades. This dramatically increases the radius of the blinding effect. Even with a small change, this would be a highly recommended perk (as nothing else in the game has been able to influence the blind radius), but the change is actually significant. A crucial pairing.|tags:PvE
dimwishlist:item=304659313&perks=3525010810,3032599245,3161816588,960810156
dimwishlist:item=304659313&perks=3798852852,3032599245,3161816588,960810156
dimwishlist:item=304659313&perks=3032599245,3161816588,960810156

//Ignition Code
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Slideshot is a game changer here, and I mean that literally: you will have to adapt your playstyle, and get used to sliding after every shot, but once you make the adjustments, this becomes a grenade launcher that functions like they did in the old luna-reload days, able to pump out shots as fast as its RPM, with reloading entirely removed from the equation. However, you can do so while on the move, making for an absolute terror in crucible as long as you have some special bricks around. Spike vs Proximity is up to preference: the former requires direct hits but can kill with a single shot, the latter is better suited for peppering shots in the opponent's general direction.|tags:PvP
dimwishlist:item=304659313&perks=981914802,3301904089,3161816588,3523296417

//Fatebringer
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): Not a huge fan of Rewind Rounds in their current state, for a couple reasons. For one, missing the final shot seems to completely nullify the refund. Secondly, the 50% refund means that eventually you will have to reload, and I'd always rather recommend a roll that has a *consistently* high reload speed than a diminishing mag extension that can run out at the wrong time. Firefly seems to mitigate the second issue, as the explosion hits also count towards the total the refund is calculated from, further extending the mag, which combined with Firefly's built-in reload boost can save you from ever having to do a slow reload. Since you'll always want Firefly in Slot 4, Rewind Rounds becomes a workable option. That being said, if possible, I'd opt for Explosive Payload (for its anti-champion utility and damage falloff mitigation) or Thresh, which this weapon uniquely rolls in Slot 3—all other Thresh weapons force you to trade in a damage perk for it, whereas this one can combine it with the AOE of Firefly.|tags:PvE

//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content): Not a huge fan of Rewind Rounds in their current state, for a couple reasons. For one, missing the final shot seems to completely nullify the refund. Secondly, the 50% refund means that eventually you will have to reload, and I'd always rather recommend a roll that has a *consistently* high reload speed than a diminishing mag extension that can run out at the wrong time. Firefly seems to mitigate the second issue, as the explosion hits also count towards the total the refund is calculated from, further extending the mag, which combined with Firefly's built-in reload boost can save you from ever having to do a slow reload. Since you'll always want Firefly in Slot 4, Rewind Rounds becomes a workable option. That being said, if possible, I'd opt for Explosive Payload (for its anti-champion utility and damage falloff mitigation) or Thresh, which this weapon uniquely rolls in Slot 3—all other Thresh weapons force you to trade in a damage perk for it, whereas this one can combine it with the AOE of Firefly.|tags:PvE

//Fatebringer
//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs / optimal): Not a huge fan of Rewind Rounds in their current state, for a couple reasons. For one, missing the final shot seems to completely nullify the refund. Secondly, the 50% refund means that eventually you will have to reload, and I'd always rather recommend a roll that has a *consistently* high reload speed than a diminishing mag extension that can run out at the wrong time. Firefly seems to mitigate the second issue, as the explosion hits also count towards the total the refund is calculated from, further extending the mag, which combined with Firefly's built-in reload boost can save you from ever having to do a slow reload. Since you'll always want Firefly in Slot 4, Rewind Rounds becomes a workable option. That being said, if possible, I'd opt for Explosive Payload (for its anti-champion utility and damage falloff mitigation) or Thresh, which this weapon uniquely rolls in Slot 3—all other Thresh weapons force you to trade in a damage perk for it, whereas this one can combine it with the AOE of Firefly.|tags:PvE

//Fatebringer
//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs): Not a huge fan of Rewind Rounds in their current state, for a couple reasons. For one, missing the final shot seems to completely nullify the refund. Secondly, the 50% refund means that eventually you will have to reload, and I'd always rather recommend a roll that has a *consistently* high reload speed than a diminishing mag extension that can run out at the wrong time. Firefly seems to mitigate the second issue, as the explosion hits also count towards the total the refund is calculated from, further extending the mag, which combined with Firefly's built-in reload boost can save you from ever having to do a slow reload. Since you'll always want Firefly in Slot 4, Rewind Rounds becomes a workable option. That being said, if possible, I'd opt for Explosive Payload (for its anti-champion utility and damage falloff mitigation) or Thresh, which this weapon uniquely rolls in Slot 3—all other Thresh weapons force you to trade in a damage perk for it, whereas this one can combine it with the AOE of Firefly.|tags:PvE

//Fatebringer
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Right now, 140s are still lagging behind 120s but it's worth keeping a good roll of this for any future meta shakeups. Killing Wind + Kill Clip or Firefly are potent combinations for chaining kills. As always, I slightly prefer a roll that gets you the first kill more consistently, and Explosive Payload—with its increased flinching effect and damage falloff mitigation—paired with Opening Shot should do the best job. As the Slot 3 recommended perks both come with a Range increase (which Opening Shot can push even farther), I'd recommend a Handling focus in either Slot 1 or on the MW.|tags:PvP

//Fatebringer (Timelost)
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): Not a huge fan of Rewind Rounds in their current state, for a couple reasons. For one, missing the final shot seems to completely nullify the refund. Secondly, the 50% refund means that eventually you will have to reload, and I'd always rather recommend a roll that has a *consistently* high reload speed than a diminishing mag extension that can run out at the wrong time. Firefly seems to mitigate the second issue, as the explosion hits also count towards the total the refund is calculated from, further extending the mag, which combined with Firefly's built-in reload boost can save you from ever having to do a slow reload. Since you'll always want Firefly in Slot 4, Rewind Rounds becomes a workable option. That being said, if possible, I'd opt for Explosive Payload (for its anti-champion utility and damage falloff mitigation) or Thresh, which this weapon uniquely rolls in Slot 3—all other Thresh weapons force you to trade in a damage perk for it, whereas this one can combine it with the AOE of Firefly.|tags:PvE

//Fatebringer (Timelost)
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content): Not a huge fan of Rewind Rounds in their current state, for a couple reasons. For one, missing the final shot seems to completely nullify the refund. Secondly, the 50% refund means that eventually you will have to reload, and I'd always rather recommend a roll that has a *consistently* high reload speed than a diminishing mag extension that can run out at the wrong time. Firefly seems to mitigate the second issue, as the explosion hits also count towards the total the refund is calculated from, further extending the mag, which combined with Firefly's built-in reload boost can save you from ever having to do a slow reload. Since you'll always want Firefly in Slot 4, Rewind Rounds becomes a workable option. That being said, if possible, I'd opt for Explosive Payload (for its anti-champion utility and damage falloff mitigation) or Thresh, which this weapon uniquely rolls in Slot 3—all other Thresh weapons force you to trade in a damage perk for it, whereas this one can combine it with the AOE of Firefly.|tags:PvE

//Fatebringer (Timelost)
//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs / optimal): Not a huge fan of Rewind Rounds in their current state, for a couple reasons. For one, missing the final shot seems to completely nullify the refund. Secondly, the 50% refund means that eventually you will have to reload, and I'd always rather recommend a roll that has a *consistently* high reload speed than a diminishing mag extension that can run out at the wrong time. Firefly seems to mitigate the second issue, as the explosion hits also count towards the total the refund is calculated from, further extending the mag, which combined with Firefly's built-in reload boost can save you from ever having to do a slow reload. Since you'll always want Firefly in Slot 4, Rewind Rounds becomes a workable option. That being said, if possible, I'd opt for Explosive Payload (for its anti-champion utility and damage falloff mitigation) or Thresh, which this weapon uniquely rolls in Slot 3—all other Thresh weapons force you to trade in a damage perk for it, whereas this one can combine it with the AOE of Firefly.|tags:PvE

//Fatebringer (Timelost)
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Right now, 140s are still lagging behind 120s but it's worth keeping a good roll of this for any future meta shakeups. Killing Wind + Kill Clip or Firefly are potent combinations for chaining kills. As always, I slightly prefer a roll that gets you the first kill more consistently, and Explosive Payload—with its increased flinching effect and damage falloff mitigation—paired with Opening Shot should do the best job. As the Slot 3 recommended perks both come with a Range increase (which Opening Shot can push even farther), I'd recommend a Handling focus in either Slot 1 or on the MW.|tags:PvP

//Vision of Confluence
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): Not a huge fan of Rewind Rounds in their current state, for a couple reasons. For one, missing the final shot seems to completely nullify the refund. Secondly, the 50% refund means that eventually you will have to reload, and I'd always rather recommend a roll that has a *consistently* high reload speed than a diminishing mag extension that can run out at the wrong time. Firefly seems to mitigate the second issue, as the explosion hits also count towards the total the refund is calculated from, further extending the mag, which combined with Firefly's built-in reload boost can save you from ever having to do a slow reload. With that combination, Rewind Rounds becomes a workable option but if possible, I'd shoot for Wellspring, which this weapon uniquely rolls in Slot 3—all other Wellspring weapons force you to trade in a damage perk for it, whereas this one can combine it with the AOE of Firefly.|tags:PvE

//Vision of Confluence
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content): Not a huge fan of Rewind Rounds in their current state, for a couple reasons. For one, missing the final shot seems to completely nullify the refund. Secondly, the 50% refund means that eventually you will have to reload, and I'd always rather recommend a roll that has a *consistently* high reload speed than a diminishing mag extension that can run out at the wrong time. Firefly seems to mitigate the second issue, as the explosion hits also count towards the total the refund is calculated from, further extending the mag, which combined with Firefly's built-in reload boost can save you from ever having to do a slow reload. With that combination, Rewind Rounds becomes a workable option but if possible, I'd shoot for Wellspring, which this weapon uniquely rolls in Slot 3—all other Wellspring weapons force you to trade in a damage perk for it, whereas this one can combine it with the AOE of Firefly.|tags:PvE

//Vision of Confluence
//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs / optimal): Not a huge fan of Rewind Rounds in their current state, for a couple reasons. For one, missing the final shot seems to completely nullify the refund. Secondly, the 50% refund means that eventually you will have to reload, and I'd always rather recommend a roll that has a *consistently* high reload speed than a diminishing mag extension that can run out at the wrong time. Firefly seems to mitigate the second issue, as the explosion hits also count towards the total the refund is calculated from, further extending the mag, which combined with Firefly's built-in reload boost can save you from ever having to do a slow reload. With that combination, Rewind Rounds becomes a workable option but if possible, I'd shoot for Wellspring, which this weapon uniquely rolls in Slot 3—all other Wellspring weapons force you to trade in a damage perk for it, whereas this one can combine it with the AOE of Firefly.|tags:PvE

//Vision of Confluence
//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs): Not a huge fan of Rewind Rounds in their current state, for a couple reasons. For one, missing the final shot seems to completely nullify the refund. Secondly, the 50% refund means that eventually you will have to reload, and I'd always rather recommend a roll that has a *consistently* high reload speed than a diminishing mag extension that can run out at the wrong time. Firefly seems to mitigate the second issue, as the explosion hits also count towards the total the refund is calculated from, further extending the mag, which combined with Firefly's built-in reload boost can save you from ever having to do a slow reload. With that combination, Rewind Rounds becomes a workable option but if possible, I'd shoot for Wellspring, which this weapon uniquely rolls in Slot 3—all other Wellspring weapons force you to trade in a damage perk for it, whereas this one can combine it with the AOE of Firefly.|tags:PvE

//Vision of Confluence
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Big damage increase perks are important for this archetype: by default, it has the slowest TTK among scout rifles but something like Kill Clip transforms it into the fastest one in the family, even surpassing Dead Man's Tale. Since we're already using a perk that activates after the first kill, it makes sense to double down on that effect: Tunnel Vision is your best option, partly because it procs at the same time as Kill Clip (with the reload following the kill), and also due to its aim assist boost which will help get the 3 headshots required for the optimal TTK. Killing Wind is your second best option: while the Range boost doesn't matter much considering the high base range on scouts, the Mobility and Handling bonuses should prove useful.|tags:PvP
dimwishlist:item=3186018373&perks=839105230,1561002382,2946784966,1015611457
dimwishlist:item=3186018373&perks=1840239774,1561002382,2946784966,1015611457

dimwishlist:item=3186018373&perks=1561002382,2946784966,1015611457

//Vision of Confluence

Since we're already using a perk that activates after the first kill, it makes sense to double down on that effect: Tunnel Vision is your best option, partly because it procs at the same time as Kill Clip (with the reload following the kill), and also due to its aim assist boost which will help get the 3 headshots required for the optimal TTK. Killing Wind is your second best option: while the Range boost doesn't matter much considering the high base range on scouts, the Mobility and Handling bonuses should prove useful.|tags:PvP

//Vision of Confluence (Timelost)
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): Not a huge fan of Rewind Rounds in their current state, for a couple reasons. For one, missing the final shot seems to completely nullify the refund. Secondly, the 50% refund means that eventually you will have to reload, and I'd always rather recommend a roll that has a *consistently* high reload speed than a diminishing mag extension that can run out at the wrong time. Firefly seems to mitigate the second issue, as the explosion hits also count towards the total the refund is calculated from, further extending the mag, which combined with Firefly's built-in reload boost can save you from ever having to do a slow reload. With that combination, Rewind Rounds becomes a workable option but if possible, I'd shoot for Wellspring, which this weapon uniquely rolls in Slot 3—all other Wellspring weapons force you to trade in a damage perk for it, whereas this one can combine it with the AOE of Firefly.|tags:PvE

//Vision of Confluence (Timelost)
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content): Not a huge fan of Rewind Rounds in their current state, for a couple reasons. For one, missing the final shot seems to completely nullify the refund. Secondly, the 50% refund means that eventually you will have to reload, and I'd always rather recommend a roll that has a *consistently* high reload speed than a diminishing mag extension that can run out at the wrong time. Firefly seems to mitigate the second issue, as the explosion hits also count towards the total the refund is calculated from, further extending the mag, which combined with Firefly's built-in reload boost can save you from ever having to do a slow reload. With that combination, Rewind Rounds becomes a workable option but if possible, I'd shoot for Wellspring, which this weapon uniquely rolls in Slot 3—all other Wellspring weapons force you to trade in a damage perk for it, whereas this one can combine it with the AOE of Firefly.|tags:PvE

//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs): Not a huge fan of Rewind Rounds in their current state, for a couple reasons. For one, missing the final shot seems to completely nullify the refund. //Vision of Confluence (Timelost)
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Big damage increase perks are important for this archetype: by default, it has the slowest TTK among scout rifles but something like Kill Clip transforms it into the fastest one in the family, even surpassing Dead Man's Tale. Since we're already using a perk that activates after the first kill, it makes sense to double down on that effect: Tunnel Vision is your best option, partly because it procs at the same time as Kill Clip (with the reload following the kill), and also due to its aim assist boost which will help get the 3 headshots required for the optimal TTK. Killing Wind is your second best option: while the Range boost doesn't matter much considering the high base range on scouts, the Mobility and Handling bonuses should prove useful.|tags:PvP
dimwishlist:item=690668916&perks=839105230,1561002382,2946784966,1015611457
dimwishlist:item=690668916&perks=1840239774,1561002382,2946784966,1015611457
dimwishlist:item=690668916&perks=3661387068,1561002382,2946784966,1015611457
dimwishlist:item=690668916&perks=1561002382,2946784966,1015611457

Killing Wind is your second best option: while the Range boost doesn't matter much considering the high base range on scouts, the Mobility and Handling bonuses should prove useful.|tags:PvP

//Praedyth's Revenge
//notes: adam (PvE / boss dps / optimal): This roll is the highest-DPS legendary sniper rifle in the game, which should be a must have, except it's currently impossible to utilize effectively: in order to accomplish that optimal DPS, you need to hit rapid precision shots at the max rate of fire, which is easy to do with a Divinity bubble, but Rewind Rounds does not proc on hits dealt to the Divinity cage. I am hoping that this is unintentional, and will get patched so this weapon can become more than just a *theoretical* best-in-class.|tags:PvE

I am hoping that this is unintentional, and will get patched so this weapon can become more than just a *theoretical* best-in-class.|tags:PvE

//Found Verdict
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Have you ever thought to yourself "this game really needs another version of Felwinter's Lie, but with better stats across the board"? Well, me neither, but here it is. Might as well make sure you have a good roll on it. Felwinter could still remain superior due to its unique, intrinsic "shot package" perk, but this can get some slightly different rolls (particularly the combo of Full Auto and Assault Mag, both of which provide an RPM increase, making it less of a death sentence to miss the kill on your first shot), and it deals Arc damage, which could render it the rare counter to generally unkillable Heir Apparent users.|tags:PvP

//Found Verdict (Timelost)
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Have you ever thought to yourself "this game really needs another version of Felwinter's Lie, but with better stats across the board"? Well, me neither, but here it is. Might as well make sure you have a good roll on it. Felwinter could still remain superior due to its unique, intrinsic "shot package" perk, but this can get some slightly different rolls (particularly the combo of Full Auto and Assault Mag, both of which provide an RPM increase, making it less of a death sentence to miss the kill on your first shot), and it deals Arc damage, which could render it the rare counter to generally unkillable Heir Apparent users.|tags:PvP

//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): Great options for reload perks here, and I'd opt for the least traditional one: Demolitionist feels like a sufficient reload perk on an LMG—with the amount of adds you can take down with a single mag, it shouldn't be too difficult to get a full grenade charge before you run out. Furthermore, this is the only weapon in the game that can roll Demolitionist and Adrenaline Junkie together, transforming your grenades into a tool that both reloads your weapon and increases its damage.|tags:PvE

//Corrective Measure
//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs / optimal): One For All remains the best damage perk for difficult content due to the magnitude of the damage increase and to its easy activation regardless of enemy health. However, since Demolitionist seems like the obvious choice in Slot 3, Adrenaline Junkie can serve as a substitute damage perk thanks to the synergy those two perks provide together. Lastly, Thresh can make this a good pick for someone using a super-refund exotic to top off the remaining chunk and get those super chains going faster.|tags:PvE

//Corrective Measure
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): PvP heavy bricks give more ammo the higher your mag size, so you will either need Extended Mag here or you will want a Backup Mag on the weapon to get to max ammo per brick. Extended + Backup Mag gives no extra ammo pickup so if you manage to roll Extended, you are free to use any other mod on the weapon. High-Impact Reserves will always be active, as the ammo you get from a brick is less than half your mag size.|tags:PvP

//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): Great options for reload perks here, and I'd opt for the least traditional one: Demolitionist feels like a sufficient reload perk on an LMG—with the amount of adds you can take down with a single mag, it shouldn't be too difficult to get a full grenade charge before you run out. Furthermore, this is the only weapon in the game that can roll Demolitionist and Adrenaline Junkie together, transforming your grenades into a tool that both reloads your weapon and increases its damage.|tags:PvE

//Corrective Measure (Timelost)
//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs / optimal): One For All remains the best damage perk for difficult content due to the magnitude of the damage increase and to its easy activation regardless of enemy health. However, since Demolitionist seems like the obvious choice in Slot 3, Adrenaline Junkie can serve as a substitute damage perk thanks to the synergy those two perks provide together. Lastly, Thresh can make this a good pick for someone using a super-refund exotic to top off the remaining chunk and get those super chains going faster.|tags:PvE

//Corrective Measure (Timelost)
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): PvP heavy bricks give more ammo the higher your mag size, so you will either need Extended Mag here or you will want a Backup Mag on the weapon to get to max ammo per brick. Extended + Backup Mag gives no extra ammo pickup so if you manage to roll Extended, you are free to use any other mod on the weapon. High-Impact Reserves will always be active, as the ammo you get from a brick is less than half your mag size.|tags:PvP

//Hezen Vengeance
//notes: adam (PvE / general use / optimal): With Lasting Impression, this is basically the exact same weapon as the same roll on Code Duello, and it's merely providing you with another option to secure that coveted perk combination. Vorpal is another option in Slot 4: it gives a slightly smaller damage bonus than Lasting Impression (and only against bosses, though everything else will probably die to a single rocket anyways, so this caveat shouldn't matter much), but the rockets detonate instantly, which can help on timed, short damage phases. However, it also takes away the solo option of switching to Divinity after firing to increase your own Lasting Impression rocket's explosion damage.|tags:PvE
dimwishlist:item=4050645223&perks=3525010810,3796465595,3300816228,3927722942
dimwishlist:item=4050645223&perks=3525010810,3300816228,3927722942
dimwishlist:item=4050645223&perks=3796465595,3300816228,3927722942
dimwishlist:item=4050645223&perks=3300816228,3927722942

//notes: adam (PvE / general use): With Lasting Impression, this is basically the exact same weapon as the same roll on Code Duello, and it's merely providing you with another option to secure that coveted perk combination. However, it also takes away the solo option of switching to Divinity after firing to increase your own Lasting Impression rocket's explosion damage.|tags:PvE

//Hezen Vengeance
//notes: adam (PvE / boss dps / optimal): Overflow is unique to this rocket launcher, which can make it worth pursuing. That being said, it is highly reliant on ammo RNG, and I'd be reluctant to use it outside of some raid boss encounters where you can use special finishers to stack up ammo boxes in a specific spot, allowing you to fire off all your rockets in quick succession. |tags:PvE

//Borrowed Time
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): As a 750rpm energy SMG, this should be evaluated relative to Ikelos SMG: it has worse base stats across the board, lacks Seraph Rounds, and has a harder time making warmind cells (yes, Dragonfly + Wrath of Rasputin would work, but if you're gonna go for a warmind cell build, why wouldn't you just run Ikelos?). So what options can we find here that provide a use case for this weapon?? It comes down to the availability of better damage perks which Ikelos doesn't have access to, particularly One For All, which is exceptionally quick and easy to proc on an SMG. Rampage and Dragonfly are also decent options, as is Surrounded—but that can also roll on Ikelos, so I'd only go with that roll if you don't already have an Ikelos with it. For now, I'd still stick to Ikelos and the power of warmind cells—but with the teased warmind cell nerf looming on the horizon, it's a good idea to have a strong roll of this weapon in your vault.|tags:PvE

//Borrowed Time
//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs / optimal): As a 750rpm energy SMG, this should be evaluated relative to Ikelos SMG: it has worse base stats across the board, lacks Seraph Rounds, and has a harder time making warmind cells (yes, Dragonfly + Wrath of Rasputin would work, but if you're gonna go for a warmind cell build, why wouldn't you just run Ikelos?). So what options can we find here that provide a use case for this weapon? It comes down to the availability of better damage perks which Ikelos doesn't have access to, particularly One For All, which is exceptionally quick and easy to proc on an SMG, and your best option in difficult content. Otherwise, the various ability regen perks could also prove useful (though Demolitionist is also available on Ikelos), especially considering that Surplus is your best bet for a reload perk that doesn't require proximity to dangerous enemies (like Threat Detector).|tags:PvE

//Borrowed Time
//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs): As a 750rpm energy SMG, this should be evaluated relative to Ikelos SMG: it has worse base stats across the board, lacks Seraph Rounds, and has a harder time making warmind cells (yes, Dragonfly + Wrath of Rasputin would work, but if you're gonna go for a warmind cell build, why wouldn't you just run Ikelos?). So what options can we find here that provide a use case for this weapon? It comes down to the availability of better damage perks which Ikelos doesn't have access to, particularly One For All, which is exceptionally quick and easy to proc on an SMG, and your best option in difficult content. Otherwise, the various ability regen perks could also prove useful (though Demolitionist is also available on Ikelos), especially considering that Surplus is your best bet for a reload perk that doesn't require proximity to dangerous enemies (like Threat Detector).|tags:PvE

//Survivor's Epitaph
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): If you're going to use a 180rpm hand cannon in the crucible, make it this one. Why would you want to use one? Well, with Kill Clip or Multikill Clip, you can 3-tap opponents, leading to a very competitive TTK. Pair that with the high accuracy and stability this archetype possesses in general, and you've got a weapon that can stand up to its harder-hitting relatives. The tradeoff between regular Kill Clip and Multikill Clip is between uptime and ease of use: Kill Clip lets you kill guardians with just 2 crits and 1 body shot, and cannot be refreshed before it expries. Multikill Clip, on the other hand, requires 3 crits for the kill but can be refreshed every time you down a guardian.|tags:PvP

dimwishlist:item=310708513&perks=3161816588,2458213969

//Survivor's Epitaph
//notes: adam (PvP): If you're going to use a 180rpm hand cannon in the crucible, make it this one. Why would you want to use one? Well, with Kill Clip or Multikill Clip, you can 3-tap opponents, leading to a very competitive TTK. Pair that with the high accuracy and stability this archetype possesses in general, and you've got a weapon that can stand up to its harder-hitting relatives. The tradeoff between regular Kill Clip and Multikill Clip is between uptime and ease of use: Kill Clip lets you kill guardians with just 2 crits and 1 body shot, and cannot be refreshed before it expries. Multikill Clip, on the other hand, requires 3 crits for the kill but can be refreshed every time you down a guardian.|tags:PvP

//Empty Vessel
//notes: adam (PvE / blinding / optimal): Danger Zone is a truly special perk when it comes to Blinding Grenade builds: Blinding Grenades apply a -200 Blast Radius penalty, which normally ensures that any GL that has them equipped has the same minimum Blast Radius, no matter how many stat boosts you stack onto them. However, when active, Danger Zone seems to set the weapon's Blast Radius to max, ignoring any stat modifiers like the one applied by Blinding Grenades. This dramatically increases the radius of the blinding effect. Even with a small change, this would be a highly recommended perk (as nothing else in the game has been able to influence the blind radius), but the change is actually significant. A crucial pairing.|tags:PvE
dimwishlist:item=4255586669&perks=3525010810,3032599245,3300816228,960810156
dimwishlist:item=4255586669&perks=3798852852,3032599245,3300816228,960810156
dimwishlist:item=4255586669&perks=3032599245,3300816228,960810156

//Empty Vessel
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): It's rare to hit a direct hit with a breech launcher, and if you fail to do so, you will need to swap to your primary for the cleanup. This is where Disruption Break comes in, giving a whopping 50% damage boost to your kinetic primary as long as the GL does enough damage to break the opponent's shield.|tags:PvP

//Hung Jury SR4
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): You can probably get away without a damage boost in low tier content, and the fun factor of Firefly should not be underestimated. That being said, this is one of lowest DPS primary weapon archetypes in the entire game, and the fast fire rate lets you proc One For All very quickly. For all the other slots, I'd mostly prioritize reload boosts, with stability as a second focus.|tags:PvE

//Hung Jury SR4
//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs / optimal): This is one of lowest DPS primary weapon archetypes in the entire game, so One For All feels even more mandatory here than usual. I rank Explosive Payload next to it for most weapons but since scout rifles don't really have to worry about damage falloff, its effects are less potent here; the constant damage multiplier will serve you better. Rapid Hit is an easy-upkeep reload perk in GMs so I'd go for mag increases in Slot 2, and some Stability in Slot 1.|tags:PvE

//Hung Jury SR4
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Box Breathing lets you kill in one fewer shot, transforming this from one the slowest TTK scout archetype to the fastest one. It fosters a playstyle that's kind of out of place in the current meta, requiring you to just stand around scoped in for a long time, opening you up to shotgun flankers. Still, it's the only way this weapon can be competitive, so if you like standing back and picking people off from long range, this roll will serve you well. Moving Target is a good pairing: it procs on ADS, and that's what you will always be doing. Rapid Hit is another strong option on scouts for the stability increase. On that note, I'd stack stability and recoil boosts in the first two slots to make it easier to hit shots.|tags:PvP

//Hung Jury SR4 (Adept)
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): You can probably get away without a damage boost in low tier content, and the fun factor of Firefly should not be underestimated. That being said, this is one of lowest DPS primary weapon archetypes in the entire game, and the fast fire rate lets you proc One For All very quickly. For all the other slots, I'd mostly prioritize reload boosts, with stability as a second focus.|tags:PvE

//notes: adam (PvE / high PL content, GMs / optimal): This is one of lowest DPS primary weapon archetypes in the entire game, so One For All feels even more mandatory here than usual. I rank Explosive Payload next to it for most weapons but since scout rifles don't really have to worry about damage falloff, its effects are less potent here; the constant damage multiplier will serve you better. Rapid Hit is an easy-upkeep reload perk in GMs so I'd go for mag increases in Slot 2, and some Stability in Slot 1.|tags:PvE

//Hung Jury SR4 (Adept)
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Box Breathing lets you kill in one fewer shot, transforming this from one the slowest TTK scout archetype to the fastest one. It fosters a playstyle that's kind of out of place in the current meta, requiring you to just stand around scoped in for a long time, opening you up to shotgun flankers. Still, it's the only way this weapon can be competitive, so if you like standing back and picking people off from long range, this roll will serve you well. Moving Target is a good pairing: it procs on ADS, and that's what you will always be doing. Rapid Hit is another strong option on scouts for the stability increase. On that note, I'd stack stability and recoil boosts in the first two slots to make it easier to hit shots.|tags:PvP

//PLUG ONE.1
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): High-Impact Fusions are still way too dominant in PvP for me to really recommend a different archetype but this one has some strong perk combinations that could make it a surprise hit if they ever substantially change the fusion rifle status quo. Stability and Recoil are important on fusions as they determine how closely your bolts are grouped together, and this one can push them really high with the right combo. Kickstart vs Cornered is up to personal preference: the latter is more situational due to its proc conditions but should greatly increase the weapon's lethality if you do get it going, the former is entirely in your control but is only active for a very short window, requiring you to always fire while sliding.|tags:PvP

//PLUG ONE.1 (Adept)
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): High-Impact Fusions are still way too dominant in PvP for me to really recommend a different archetype but this one has some strong perk combinations that could make it a surprise hit if they ever substantially change the fusion rifle status quo. Stability and Recoil are important on fusions as they determine how closely your bolts are grouped together, and this one can push them really high with the right combo. Kickstart vs Cornered is up to personal preference: the latter is more situational due to its proc conditions but should greatly increase the weapon's lethality if you do get it going, the former is entirely in your control but is only active for a very short window, requiring you to always fire while sliding.|tags:PvP

//Uzume RR4
//notes: adam (PvE / optimal): A better version of Adored, thanks to the ability to roll mag increases, which will allow for extra procs of Triple Tap. For the maximum uptime, you will also want a Backup Mag mod on it. While Clown Cartridge can result in similar DPS numbers, I prefer Triple Tap because it refunds ammo from thin air (not reserves), helping with your ammo economy and increasing the total number of shots you get to fire.|tags:PvE

//Uzume RR4
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Every sniper with snapshot can be someone's favorite. This one has 50 Zoom, which is equivalent to a lot of the popular snipers at the moment (Succession, Frozen Orbit, Cloudstrike). If you've been using those and wanted an Adaptive Frame option with the same Zoom, this is your pick. If you need a lower zoom, Adored is right there (though this also has the advantage of being able to roll Snapshot + Vorpal together, a combo that can be necessary against certain supers).|tags:PvP

//Uzume RR4 (Adept)
//notes: adam (PvE / optimal): A better version of Adored, thanks to the ability to roll mag increases, which will allow for extra procs of Triple Tap. For the maximum uptime, you will also want a Backup Mag mod on it. While Clown Cartridge can result in similar DPS numbers, I prefer Triple Tap because it refunds ammo from thin air (not reserves), helping with your ammo economy and increasing the total number of shots you get to fire.|tags:PvE

//Uzume RR4 (Adept)
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): Every sniper with snapshot can be someone's favorite. This one has 50 Zoom, which is equivalent to a lot of the popular snipers at the moment (Succession, Frozen Orbit, Cloudstrike). If you've been using those and wanted an Adaptive Frame option with the same Zoom, this is your pick. If you need a lower zoom, Adored is right there (though this also has the advantage of being able to roll Snapshot + Vorpal together, a combo that can be necessary against certain supers).|tags:PvP

//The Messenger
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): In low level content, where you can continuously chain it, Desperado basically functions as a damage buff (and it's the fun unique thing on this weapon, which matters). Otherwise, One For All is a great damage perk option. Slot 2 and 3 have the usual suspects, and Slot 1 should be focused on Recoil and Handling boosts. On the subject of recoil: I would always run a Counterbalance mod on this weapon, it's the only way to make the normally strongly side-pulling recoil pattern completely vertical.|tags:PvE

//The Messenger
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): An astounding perk selection on this one, especially in Slot 3, where there is no bad option. In Slot 4, Desperado is the popular, unique option but I think there is a case to be made for Headseeker which gives you a more forgiving 2-tap potential on *every* kill, even before you get that first elimination. It's a risk/reward decision you will have to make based on personal preference (or, more realistically, on what Saint is willing to drop for you). If I had to pick two from the great options Slot 3, I'd go with either Rapid Hit or Moving Target, to further increase consistency by increasing stability and aim assist, respectively (of course, Rapid Hit also helps with the reloads if you end up going with Desperado or Kill Clip). Slot 1 should be focused on Recoil and Handling boosts. On the subject of recoil: I would always run a Counterbalance mod on this weapon, it's the only way to make the normally strongly side-pulling recoil pattern completely vertical.|tags:PvP

//The Messenger
//notes: adam (PvP): An astounding perk selection on this one, especially in Slot 3, where there is no bad option. In Slot 4, Desperado is the popular, unique option but I think there is a case to be made for Headseeker which gives you a more forgiving 2-tap potential on *every* kill, even before you get that first elimination. It's a risk/reward decision you will have to make based on personal preference (or, more realistically, on what Saint is willing to drop for you). If I had to pick two from the great options Slot 3, I'd go with either Rapid Hit or Moving Target, to further increase consistency by increasing stability and aim assist, respectively (of course, Rapid Hit also helps with the reloads if you end up going with Desperado or Kill Clip). Slot 1 should be focused on Recoil and Handling boosts. On the subject of recoil: I would always run a Counterbalance mod on this weapon, it's the only way to make the normally strongly side-pulling recoil pattern completely vertical.|tags:PvP

//The Messenger (Adept)
//notes: adam (PvE / regular, non-endgame content / optimal): In low level content, where you can continuously chain it, Desperado basically functions as a damage buff (and it's the fun unique thing on this weapon, which matters). Otherwise, One For All is a great damage perk option. Slot 2 and 3 have the usual suspects, and Slot 1 should be focused on Recoil and Handling boosts. On the subject of recoil: I would always run a Counterbalance mod on this weapon, it's the only way to make the normally strongly side-pulling recoil pattern completely vertical.|tags:PvE

Slot 1 should be focused on Recoil and Handling boosts. On the subject of recoil: I would always run a Counterbalance mod on this weapon, it's the only way to make the normally strongly side-pulling recoil pattern completely vertical.|tags:PvE

//The Messenger (Adept)
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): An astounding perk selection on this one, especially in Slot 3, where there is no bad option. In Slot 4, Desperado is the popular, unique option but I think there is a case to be made for Headseeker which gives you a more forgiving 2-tap potential on *every* kill, even before you get that first elimination. It's a risk/reward decision you will have to make based on personal preference (or, more realistically, on what Saint is willing to drop for you). If I had to pick two from the great options Slot 3, I'd go with either Rapid Hit or Moving Target, to further increase consistency by increasing stability and aim assist, respectively (of course, Rapid Hit also helps with the reloads if you end up going with Desperado or Kill Clip). Slot 1 should be focused on Recoil and Handling boosts. On the subject of recoil: I would always run a Counterbalance mod on this weapon, it's the only way to make the normally strongly side-pulling recoil pattern completely vertical.|tags:PvP

//The Messenger (Adept)
//notes: adam (PvP): An astounding perk selection on this one, especially in Slot 3, where there is no bad option. In Slot 4, Desperado is the popular, unique option but I think there is a case to be made for Headseeker which gives you a more forgiving 2-tap potential on *every* kill, even before you get that first elimination. It's a risk/reward decision you will have to make based on personal preference (or, more realistically, on what Saint is willing to drop for you). If I had to pick two from the great options Slot 3, I'd go with either Rapid Hit or Moving Target, to further increase consistency by increasing stability and aim assist, respectively (of course, Rapid Hit also helps with the reloads if you end up going with Desperado or Kill Clip). Slot 1 should be focused on Recoil and Handling boosts. On the subject of recoil: I would always run a Counterbalance mod on this weapon, it's the only way to make the normally strongly side-pulling recoil pattern completely vertical.|tags:PvP

//The Scholar
//notes: adam (PvP / optimal): This is an unforgiving, high risk / high reward archetype: with all headshots, it gets the fastest scout rifle TTK but becomes the slowest if you're hitting shots to the body. Comes with low base Stability and Handling values (an inherent attribute for this archetype), and a recoil stat that pulls to the side. The recoil can be fixed with a Counterbalance mod or by putting on Arrowhead Brake in Slot 1 but the slow fire rate makes this a little less essential than on most other weapon types. Otherwise, pick the best combination of Stability + Handling increases you can find among your barrel and masterwork options. As mentioned, this archetype requires headshots to be competitive, so the main perk slots are all about consistency increasing picks.|tags:PvP
